metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Qinghai Lake integrated observatory network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Subalpine shrub, 2020
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Qinghai Lake integrated observatory network obtained from an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of the Subalpine shrub from Janurary 1to December 31, 2020. The site (100°6'3.62"E, 37°31'15.67") was located in the subalpine shrub ecosystem, near the Gangcha County, Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3495m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP155; 3, 5 and 10 m, towards north), wind speed and direction profile (windsonic; 3, 5 and 10 m, towards north), air pressure (PTB110; 3 m), rain gauge (TE525M; 2 m of the platform in west by north of tower), four-component radiometer (CNR4; 6m, towards south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, towards south, vertically downward), photosynthetically active radiation (PQS1; 6 m, towards south, each with one vertically downward and one vertically upward, soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates below the vegetation; -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109; -0.05、-0.10、-0.20、-0.40、-0.80、-1.20、-2.00、-3.00 and -4.00m), soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.05、-0.10、-0.20、-0.40、-0.80、-1.20、-2.00、-3.00 and -4.00m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_3 m, Ta_5 m, and Ta_10 m; RH_3 m, RH_5 m, and RH_10 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_3 m, Ws_5 m, and Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_3 m, WD_5 m and WD_10 m) (°), precipitation (rain) (mm), air pressure (press) (hpa), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), photosynthetically active radiation of upward and downward (PAR_D_up and PAR_D_down) (μmol/ (s m-2)), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_5cm、Ts_10cm、Ts_20cm、Ts_40cm、Ts_80cm、Ts_120cm、Ts_200cm、Ts_300cm、Ts_500cm) (℃), soil moisture (Ms_5cm、Ms_10cm、Ms_20cm、Ms_40cm、Ms_80cm、Ms_120cm、Ms_200cm、Ms_300cm、Ms_500cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2018/8/31 10:30. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.

background: Accurate monitoring of surface fluxes over land surfaces is necessary for global climate change research, ecological environment management, and agricultural and water resource planning. The magnitude of the surface flux is largely determined by vegetation parameters, soil moisture and other states of the land surface. The major methods used for estimating surface fluxes are field measurement, remote-sensing-based methods, and land surface modeling. The variability in field measurements of surface flux has been documented over diurnal, seasonal, and inter-annual time scales.

Land surface models have been rapidly developed to predict surface fluxes on continuous spatial and temporal scales with physical constraints. Regardless of their specific model structures, all land surface models require observational data to calibrate their parameters and adjust their states. New techniques such as data assimilation are needed to integrate either field or remotely sensed observations with the models, thus improving model accuracy by correcting the model state variables and parameters. Data assimilation has played an increasingly important role in improving predictions of such land surface state variables as the leaf area index, soil temperature profile, soil moisture profile, and other related variables, e.g., surface fluxes.

Spatially distributed estimates of surface flux can be obtained from remote-sensing-based methods. The surface fluxes also can be obtained based on variational techniques and relatively simple models with the assimilation of field-measured land surface temperatures. In a land surface model, the sensible and latent heat fluxes are diagnostic variables, and they are affected by many factors (e.g., model states and parameters). As a new-generation Chinese polar orbiting meteorological satellite, the FY-3 series consists of two experimental (FY-3A/B) and at least four operational satellites (FY-3C/D/E/F). The FY-3 series is expected to have a service life that lasts until 2020. The FY-3A was launched in the year 2008. Visible and infrared radiometer (VIRR) is one of the 11 sensors mounted on the FY-3A satellite and has a nominal spatial resolution of approximately 1 km×1 km at the nadir. The common land model (CoLM) is a state-of-the-art model developed by many groups and validated with extensive field data sites. In CoLM, soil moisture is important for dividing the net radiation into the ground heat, sensible, and latent heat fluxes.

Inaccurate surface flux predictions are highly correlated with errors in land surface temperature estimates. Generally, the diurnal variation trends of the land surface temperature and surface flux can be predicted correctly using the CoLM. The daily averaged evaporation fraction (EF, ratio between latent heat flux and available energy) can be used to describe the splitting of available energy into sensible and latent heat fluxes. The LAS instrument can measure the sensible heat flux at a larger scale than the EC system.
research objective: In this work, a dual-pass data assimilation scheme is developed to improve predictions of surface flux.

The current study constructed a dual-pass data assimilation scheme with an ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) to improve the surface flux predictions with assimilation of remotely sensed land surface temperature. This study carried out the first experiment to assimilate remotely sensed land surface temperatures (LST) derived from FY3A-VIRR into a land surface model.

In this study, a dual-pass data assimilation scheme was constructed to estimate the surface fluxes via the independent optimization of the soil moisture and vegetation parameters. The aim of this study was to eliminate or reduce the errors between the model simulation and observation.
challenges: Methods are difficult to use for continuous monitoring of surface fluxes because the data derived from satellites are instantaneous and often contaminated by the presence of clouds.

However, these measurements are difficult to use for monitoring surface fluxes at the regional scale because they only produce either point or patch-scale data. The deviations between the FY3A-VIRR LST data and the ground measurements are determined by many factors. The terrain effect can affect the accuracy of the FY3A-VIRR LST retrievals. The mismatch of the spatial and temporal scales between the FY3A-VIRR and field-measured LST can also cause these biases.

The differences between the sensible heat fluxes measured by the EC and LAS system are primarily caused by the energy imbalance of the EC, the heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces, and the differences between the source areas of the EC and LAS measurements. Because of the short memory of the land surface temperature, it is difficult to assimilate the land surface temperatures. Directly assimilating land surface temperature to optimize soil moisture may cause model simulations that are more unstable.
methods: In this work, a dual-pass data assimilation scheme is developed to improve predictions of surface flux. Pass 1 of the dual-pass data assimilation scheme optimizes the model vegetation parameters at the weekly temporal scale, and Pass 2 optimizes the soil moisture at the daily temporal scale. Based on ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF), the land surface temperature (LST) data derived from the new generation of Chinese meteorology satellite (FY3A-VIRR) are assimilated into common land model (CoLM) for the first time. Six sites, Daman, Guantao, Arou, BJ, Miyun and Jiyuan, are selected for the data assimilation experiments and include different climatological conditions.

The dual-pass data assimilation technique employed in this study optimizes the model states and parameters independently. The two passes of the scheme assimilate the remotely sensed land surface temperatures (LST) derived from the FY3A satellite. With the assimilation of the FY3A-VIRR LST data, Pass 1 is used to optimize the model parameters at the weekly temporal scale, and Pass 2 is used to optimize the soil moisture at the daily temporal scale. Six Chinese flux observation sites with different land cover types (alpine meadow, grassland, cropland, and orchard) were selected to conduct the data assimilation experiments. The FY3A-VIRR LST data are compared with the ground measurements.

In this study, the MODIS LAI products are incorporated directly into the model, and the vegetation parameters are optimized at the weekly temporal scale with Pass 1 of the dual-pass data assimilation scheme. At the daily temporal scale, the soil moisture is optimized with Pass 2 of the dual-pass data assimilation scheme. The land surface temperature data from the new generation Chinese meteorology satellite FY3A-VIRR were assimilated into CoLM for the first time based on the EnKF algorithm. The source areas of the LAS measurements were calculated using a footprint model and overlaid with a FY3A-VIRR pixel.
dataset: The land surface temperature (LST) data derived from the new generation of Chinese meteorology satellite (FY3A-VIRR) are assimilated into common land model (CoLM) for the first time. Six sites, Daman, Guantao, Arou, BJ, Miyun and Jiyuan, are selected for the data assimilation experiments and include different climatological conditions. The results are compared with those from a dataset generated by a multi-scale surface flux observation system that includes an automatic weather station (AWS), eddy covariance (EC) and large aperture scintillometer (LAS).

The FY-3A land surface temperature data will become the new data source for global water and energy balance research. The FY3A-VIRR LST products can provide the LST and emissivity of each pixel, and the data are stored in a hierarchical data format (HDF), which is a sinusoidal projection with a spatial resolution of 1 km. Data from six sites located in three major nature zones (western arid and semi-arid area, eastern monsoon area, and Qinghai-Tibet alpine meadow) of People’s Republic of China (PRC) are used for the data assimilation experiments.
findings: The results indicate that the dual-pass data assimilation scheme is able to reduce model uncertainties and improve predictions of surface flux with the assimilation of FY3A-VIRR LST data.

The dual-pass data assimilation scheme reduced the model uncertainties and improved the prediction abilities of the model. The average BIAS values of the six sites changed from 28.7 to 5.3 W m 2 and from 16.9 to 16.1 W m2; the average RMSE values dropped from 71.7 to 46.8 W m 2 and from 93.7 to 70.8 W m 2; and the average R-values increased from 0.75 to 0.78 and from 0.66 to 0.82, respectively. The average BIAS values of the assimilation EF results dropped from 0.21 to 0.01, the average RMSE values dropped from 0.31 to 0.15, and the average R-values increased from 0.43 to 0.73. The comparisons showed that the assimilation results match well against the LAS measurements, and the correlations between the assimilation results and LAS measurements were higher than that of the model simulations at the Daman, Guantao, Arou, BJ, and Jiyuan sites.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used for monitoring surface fluxes over land surfaces in high-altitude shrubland environments?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method for monitoring surface fluxes in high-altitude shrubland environments is the use of a comprehensive observation network, which includes sensors installed at varying heights (3m, 5m, and 10m) to measure wind speed and direction. Other instruments are used to record air temperature, relative humidity, atmospheric pressure, precipitation, soil heat flux, soil moisture, and soil temperature at different depths.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using satellite data for continuous monitoring of surface fluxes?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is that satellite data, such as those derived from the FY-3A-VIRR, are instantaneous and can be contaminated by clouds, making them difficult to use for continuous monitoring of surface fluxes at regional scales. Additionally, there can be mismatches in spatial and temporal scales between satellite data and ground measurements.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset used to improve predictions of surface fluxes through data assimilation techniques?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset used to improve predictions of surface fluxes is the land surface temperature data derived from the FY3A-VIRR satellite, which is assimilated into a common land model. This dataset is used alongside ground measurements from various sites with different land cover types to refine model predictions through a dual-pass data assimilation scheme.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'data assimilation' in the context of surface flux predictions?
Definition.Answer: Data assimilation refers to the integration of either field or remotely sensed observations with land surface models to improve model accuracy by correcting the model state variables and parameters. This process is crucial in enhancing predictions of land surface state variables, such as the leaf area index, soil temperature profile, soil moisture profile, and related variables, including surface fluxes.

Definition.Question: What are 'ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF)' techniques and how are they used in land surface modeling?
Definition.Answer: The ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) is a data assimilation technique used to improve predictions of surface fluxes by optimizing model states and parameters. In land surface modeling, EnKF is used to assimilate remotely sensed data, such as land surface temperature, into models like the common land model (CoLM), allowing for independent optimization of vegetation parameters and soil moisture, which helps reduce errors between model simulations and observations.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of using field measurement methods for surface fluxes differ from those encountered with remote-sensing-based methods?
Comparison.Answer: Field measurement methods face challenges in regional-scale monitoring due to their localized nature, whereas remote-sensing-based methods struggle with instantaneous data affected by cloud cover and require assimilation to reconcile spatial and temporal scale differences with field data.

Interpretation.Question: How can data assimilation techniques be applied to improve the accuracy of surface flux predictions in varied climate conditions?
Interpretation.Answer: Data assimilation techniques, such as the dual-pass data assimilation scheme using an ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF), can be employed to enhance surface flux predictions by optimizing vegetation parameters and soil moisture. These techniques integrate remotely sensed land surface temperature data into land surface models, addressing model uncertainties and improving prediction accuracy across different climatic conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are associated with integrating satellite-derived data into land surface models, and how might these be overcome?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include data contamination by clouds, spatial and temporal scale mismatches, and terrain effects affecting accuracy. These can be mitigated by using dual-pass data assimilation schemes that independently optimize model states and parameters, and by employing advanced techniques such as the ensemble Kalman filter to refine predictions based on satellite data like FY3A-VIRR LST.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can field measurement data be used to calibrate land surface models, and what are the potential limitations of these methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Field measurement data, such as those from automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and large aperture scintillometers, are essential for calibrating land surface models. They help adjust model parameters and states, but their use is often limited by the point or patch-scale nature of the data, which may not represent regional conditions accurately. Additionally, energy imbalances and surface heterogeneity can affect measurement reliability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately monitoring surface fluxes over land surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately monitoring surface fluxes over land surfaces are due to the variability in field measurements over diurnal, seasonal, and inter-annual time scales. Additionally, satellite-derived data are instantaneous and can be contaminated by clouds, while point or patch-scale field measurements are difficult to use for regional-scale monitoring.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the differences in sensible heat flux measurements between the EC and LAS systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The differences in sensible heat flux measurements between the EC and LAS systems are primarily caused by the energy imbalance of the EC system, the heterogeneity of the underlying surfaces, and the differences in source areas between the EC and LAS measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts of integrating land surface temperature data from satellites on the accuracy of surface flux predictions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating land surface temperature data from satellites, such as FY3A-VIRR, into models can significantly improve the accuracy of surface flux predictions by reducing model uncertainties and enhancing prediction abilities. This integration enables better alignment of model simulations with ground measurements, improving the correlation between model outcomes and actual environmental conditions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of employing a comprehensive observational network in the Qinghai Lake basin to monitor subalpine shrub meteorological elements?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to accurately monitor surface fluxes over land surfaces, which is essential for global climate change research, ecological environment management, and agricultural and water resource planning. The data collected is crucial for the calibration of land surface models and the improvement of model accuracy through data assimilation techniques.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the reasons for using a dual-pass data assimilation scheme to optimize soil moisture and vegetation parameters in surface flux prediction models?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The dual-pass data assimilation scheme is used to independently optimize soil moisture and vegetation parameters to improve surface flux predictions. This approach aims to reduce errors between model simulations and observations by assimilating remotely sensed land surface temperatures, thus enhancing the reliability of predictions and addressing challenges such as spatial and temporal scale mismatches.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to ensure the quality control and processing of meteorological data collected from a surface observation system in a subalpine shrub environment?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data quality control and processing steps include ensuring there are 144 data points per day (one every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceed physical or instrumental limits, highlighting questionable data in red, and standardizing date and time formats with date and time in the same column.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and placement strategies are used to accurately measure meteorological variables such as wind speed, air temperature, and soil moisture in a subalpine shrub area?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments are placed at various heights and positions: wind speed and direction sensors are mounted at 3m, 5m, and 10m facing north; air temperature and humidity sensors are at the same heights; pressure sensors are at 3m; a tipping bucket rain gauge is on a 2m platform; a four-component radiometer and infrared thermometers are at 6m facing south; soil heat flux plates are buried at 6cm depth facing south; soil temperature and moisture sensors are buried at various depths ranging from 5cm to 500cm, 2m east of the meteorological tower.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can dual-pass data assimilation schemes be structured to enhance the accuracy of surface flux predictions using satellite-derived land surface temperature data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A dual-pass data assimilation scheme can be structured with Pass 1 optimizing model vegetation parameters at a weekly temporal scale and Pass 2 optimizing soil moisture at a daily temporal scale. This scheme utilizes an ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) to assimilate land surface temperature data from satellites like FY3A-VIRR into land surface models such as CoLM, enhancing the predictions of surface fluxes by correcting model states and parameters.

Enablement.Question: What challenges are encountered in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of observational data in remote mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of observational data in remote mountainous regions include data gaps, which are indicated by -6999, and the need to eliminate duplicate records and outliers that exceed physical or instrumental limits. The presence of clouds and terrain effects can also impact the accuracy of remotely sensed data, such as land surface temperature, making it difficult to maintain consistent data quality in these areas.

Expectation.Question: Why might data derived from satellites be insufficient for continuous monitoring of surface fluxes in the Qinghai Lake Basin?
Expectation.Answer: Methods are difficult to use for continuous monitoring of surface fluxes because the data derived from satellites are instantaneous and often contaminated by the presence of clouds. Additionally, the mismatch of the spatial and temporal scales between satellite data and field measurements can introduce biases.

Expectation.Question: Why might assimilating land surface temperature data directly into soil moisture models cause instability in model simulations?
Expectation.Answer: Directly assimilating land surface temperature to optimize soil moisture may cause model simulations that are more unstable due to the short memory of the land surface temperature. This can lead to errors between model simulation and observation, affecting the stability of the model predictions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of current data assimilation techniques in integrating remote sensing data with land surface models for predicting surface fluxes?
Judgmental.Answer: The dual-pass data assimilation scheme developed in the field has shown effectiveness in reducing model uncertainties and improving predictions of surface flux with the assimilation of remotely sensed land surface temperature data. This approach optimizes model parameters and soil moisture independently, demonstrating improved prediction accuracy and correlation with large aperture scintillometer measurements compared to model simulations alone.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how field measurements are integrated with remote-sensing-based methods to estimate surface fluxes.
Assertion.Answer: Field measurements provide observational data required to calibrate and adjust land surface models, which are then integrated with remote-sensing-based methods using techniques like data assimilation to improve model accuracy in predicting surface fluxes.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in continuously monitoring surface fluxes using satellite-derived data.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges include the instantaneous nature of satellite data, contamination by clouds, and the mismatch of spatial and temporal scales between satellite-derived data and ground measurements, which affect the accuracy of surface flux predictions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the dual-pass data assimilation scheme improves predictions of surface flux.
Assertion.Answer: The dual-pass data assimilation scheme independently optimizes vegetation parameters and soil moisture using remotely sensed land surface temperature, reducing model uncertainties and improving surface flux predictions by better aligning model simulations with observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in using satellite-derived data for continuous monitoring of surface fluxes in land surface models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the instantaneous nature of satellite-derived data, cloud contamination, and the mismatch of spatial and temporal scales between satellite and field measurements. Terrain effects and the energy imbalance of measurement systems like EC and LAS also contribute to inaccuracies.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods for surface flux estimation over land surfaces, including field measurements and remote sensing techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection methods include field measurements such as those from automatic weather stations, eddy covariance systems, and large aperture scintillometers. Remote sensing techniques involve the assimilation of land surface temperature data from satellites like FY3A-VIRR into land surface models to estimate surface fluxes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that could complement land surface models in predicting surface fluxes more accurately.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include land surface temperature data from the FY3A-VIRR satellite, which can be integrated into models like the common land model (CoLM) through data assimilation techniques. These datasets, along with field measurements from various climatological sites, can improve model accuracy.
